advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT#2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is another french advert, not from CBS, but from an independant store "le jeu electronique". <br><br> Only the expansion module #3 was available in France and people had to buy a Colecovision if they wanted to have an Adam !</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://osaki.cool.ne.jp/hc/computer/canon/canon.html#x07">Handheld computer & Pocket calculator Museum</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>February 1983<br><br> Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The new Epson QX-10 is unlike any personal computer you've never seen. It's a computer for people who don't have the time to learn computer; a computer you can be using within minutes...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Japanese selling price was of 58.000 yen.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AN ADVERTISING FOR THE BM JR</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This french advert dated may 1980, shows the first model sold in France. It was called Victor Lambda and the company name was Lambda Systemes. This model was nothing more than an Interact computer, sold with an english documentation and a NTSC television !</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ALTAIR 'MOBILE' COURSE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Computing is very simple with the AIM65 from Rockwell"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ISAAC ASIMOV AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This surprising advert is dated 1982.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice the (rare!) DMX80 printer, the two floppy drive units and SDX FDD interface.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT. (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"A TO7 from Thomson fills the empty cells"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert says:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The new ASC8000-6 single board computer is packed with ultra-high technology: Z80 double density computer, up to 2048Kb of high speed RAM, Floppy-disk and Winchester Hard Disk controllers, DMA, up to 6 serial / 2 parallel I/O, optional 32 bit floating point processor... All on one board, fully socketed, fully documented, reliable and maintainable...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote>cover</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to François Houste and <a href="http://www.phijvmi.com" target="_blank">www.phijvmi.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert tried to convince computers newcomers that a pocket computer could do the same as a desktop computer...<br><br><font color="#666666"> Now Texas Instruments brings you a cordless compact computer that solves the same sort of problems as the Apple or IBM Personal Computer...<br><br> ...For most personal computer tasks, its 6K RAM and 34K ROM are ample...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSERT - RECTO</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The computing answer"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> IEEE INTERFACE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> The Acorn IEEE interface enables full implementation of the IEEE standard 488-1978. IEEE488 is also known, and is equivalent to IEC625-1 (in Europe), and GPIB or HP-IB (Hewlett Packard General Purpose Interface Bus)...<br> ...The interface can support a network of up to 14 other IEEE-488 compatible devices. Devices can be interconnected in a star or linear fashion. </font><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Neurons' jogging"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, AUG. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #2 </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
Virtually no information about this training board that was provided, prior to the Hektor PT602 with a Open University course called 'Microprocessors and Product Development - a course for managers'.
The choice of the microprocessor is a bit surprising as the 8049 was more a microcontroller than a true microprocessor. Later, the 8049 will be commonly found inside dot-matrix and PC keyboards.
More info needed!
Thanks to Chris Millard for the picture.
computer.name: PT501
